awd_titl_txt: Phase II IUCRC at University of North Carolina, Charlotte:  Center for Freeform Optics (CeFO)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Center for Freeform Optics (CeFO) is a partnership between the University of North Carolina at Charlotte (UNC Charlotte) and the University of Rochester (UR). CeFO is advancing research and education in the science, engineering, and applications of freeform optics through dedicated, long-term partnerships with industry and government laboratories. CeFO is motivated by the need for compact, affordable, high-performance optical systems to support the precision technologies of the 21st century. 

Freeform optics specifically enables compact optical solutions for complex light mapping as well as folding optical systems in three-dimensions. Applications with immediate benefit include 3-D imaging and visualization, augmented and virtual reality, infrared and military optical systems, efficient automotive and LED lighting, energy research, remote sensing, semiconductor manufacturing and inspection, and medical and assistive technologies. CeFO enables freeform optics to permeate the marketplace through integration of fundamental and applied research and significant advances in design, fabrication, and testing.

CeFO creates a fertile, dynamic, inclusive multidisciplinary environment to move this technology to the forefront. The partner universities are dedicated to the recruitment and retention of women and students from underrepresented groups (i.e. 34% underrepresented students in CeFO in Spring 2017) to create a diverse and skilled workforce for the 21st century.

The Center for Freeform Optics (CeFO) vertically integrates mathematics, materials science, optical science, optical instrument design, optomechanics, and precision optical manufacturing, measurement, and testing to transform the optics industry in the 21st century. CeFO constitutes a unique research environment combining the strengths of two world class research universities with specialized experiences, insights, and interdisciplinary talents for designing, building and measuring advanced optical systems. UNC Charlotte's expertise in fabrication, metrology and precision opto-mechanical design complements the University of Rochester's excellence in optical theory, design, and metrology. Research topics of immediate interest to industry include the mathematical description of freeform surfaces, the quantification of mid-spatial frequency errors on optical performance, and wave-based modeling of freeform systems and new bases for 3D optical design. Additional challenges include use of difficult optical materials, characterization and elimination of mid-spatial frequency errors, volume manufacturing (e.g. replication, molding, 3D printing), and advanced metrology for freeform surfaces. Freeform optical systems will enable innovation in sensing, imaging, visualization and diagnostic instrumentation by directing light in 3D. The partner Universities demonstrate excellent records in recruiting women and minority students (>30% of graduate students in the program). Students work with CeFO industrial members to communicate and transfer key enabling technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Overview:

Since its inception in 2013, with the completion of Phase 1 and II and the current Phase III, the Center for Freeform Optics (CeFO) has advanced pre-competitive research and education in the science, engineering, and applications of freeform optics through dedicated, long-term partnerships with industry and government laboratories based on shared value. CeFO is motivated by the need for compact, affordable, high-performance optical systems to support precision technologies of the 21st century. CeFO has catalyzed breakthrough pre-competitive research by enabling close and sustained engagement between industry innovators, world-class academic teams, and government agencies.

CeFO provides vertical integration of mathematics, optics, materials science, optical science, optical design, optomechanics, and precision optical manufacturing and testing to transform the optics industry in the 21st century. This center constitutes a unique research environment combining the strengths of two top-tier research universities with the specialized experiences, insights, and infrastructure for the design, manufacturing, testing, integration, and implementation of advanced optical systems.

CeFO has also demonstrated a commitment to education and recruiting of diverse groups in science and engineering and provided technical leadership and education to the broader optics community through the development of university accredited classes, keynote conferences, and public seminars on freeform design, fabrication, and metrology.

CeFO has been and will continue to be a mechanism to help industry partners and government agencies connect directly and efficiently with university researchers to 1) Achieve high-impact freeform optical research to meet shared and critical industrial needs; 2) Enhance U.S. global leadership in driving freeform technology development, and 3) Identify, develop, and mentor a diverse, highly skilled workforce.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Demonstrated research topics of immediate interest to industry include mathematical description of freeform surfaces spanning applications from design to metrology, design methodologies, quantification of mid spatial frequency (MSF) errors on optical performance and for tolerancing, and wave-based modeling of freeform systems and new bases for 3D optical design for both reflective and transmissive systems. Additional pre-competitive research results transferred to industry have focused on manufacturing methods and measurement of freeform optics, including the use of challenging optical materials, characterization and elimination of mid-spatial frequency errors, volume manufacturing (e.g., replication, molding), advanced freeform surface metrology for both form and mid spatial frequency errors, and in situ characterization during manufacturing. The establishment of reference datums and fiducials for freeform optics towards manufacturing has taken an important place in Center research.

Specific examples of disseminated research include design methodologies for full-field aberration-controlled wide-field-of-view imagers; roadmaps to the design of three-mirror anastigmats; productive diamond-machining parameters to enable rapid demonstration of infrared freeform imagers for defense, surveillance, and medical imaging; and the mathematical description of freeform surfaces with quantified mid-spatial frequencies to set surface specifications that deliver optimal system performance at least cost. Design-to-build capabilities developed in CeFO have been adopted by industry, for example for all-reflective electronic viewfinders, head-worn displays, compact spectrometer designs, designs for CubeSat imagers, and overall space optical systems  - and soon to extend into microscopy and automobile industry.

 

Broader Impacts:

Optical systems with freeform surfaces are ushering in the next generation of innovation in sensing, imaging, visualization, and diagnostic instrumentation by directing light not in 1D, but 3D. Novel freeform designs with 3D light paths have enabled compact optical systems to replace current in-line designs that utilize flat fold mirrors. CeFO research and innovation is enabling applications requiring freeform designs with tight form-accuracy to increase imaging and sensing capabilities and overall optical performance. Applications with immediate benefit include 3D imaging and visualization, optical transforms for wavefront coding in communication, infrared and military optical systems, efficient automotive and LED lighting, optics for energy research, remote sensing for resources, ubiquitous data collection, EUV lithography and semiconductor inspection, and medical and assistive technologies. CeFO has enabled freeform optics to permeate the marketplace through integration of fundamental theoretical discoveries and significant advances in design, fabrication, and testing.

CeFO has maintained a fertile, dynamic, and inclusive multidisciplinary environment to move freeform technology to the forefront. The participating universities are dedicated to the recruitment and retention of women and students from underrepresented groups (maintaining >35% underrepresented students in CeFO 2013-2024 and reaching ~45% in recent years). Center faculty members actively provide mentorship and support of NSF’s REU program, McNair Scholars, veterans’ programs, and a variety of technology outreach activities. Both institutions demonstrate excellent records on the enrollment of women and minority students. The aggressive recruitment of students from underrepresented groups continues as one of our top priorities. The Center continues to demonstrate its primary goal of active student involvement in research activities accelerating the understanding of freeform optical technology. Students work directly with Center industrial members to communicate and transfer key enabling technologies including design, fabrication, assembly, testing, and integration.
